quoteFirst: Lightened by the flames she floated off the bar and drifted, a huge pyramid of fire, down the river illuminating its broad expanse till all was bright as day, and revealing the shattered vessels of the fleet as they hastily steamed out of the way of their dangerous consort. Long after she had passed around the bend the light of the flames reflected on the sky marked her progress.
quoteLast: , when at almost the identical spot where the Confederate ram “Arkansas” was blown up, the fire reached the magazine and the “Mississippi” existed only in story. The shock of the explosion was felt at Port Hudson, twenty miles distant.
title: Company K, First Alabama Regiment; or, Three Years in the Confederate Service
author: Smith, Daniel P.

quoteFirst: He begged that he might be allowed to go, and his master, taking for devotion what in reality was greed, permitted him to join the hunters. quoteFirst: They came in in detached, independent parties, and I found it impossible to time them, as some of them kept very late hours. I slept in the Simud Putih cave on this occasion, and found that next morning the bats returned
quoteLast: , and that the swifts went out an hour afterwards.

quoteLast: ; the sky was cloudy, with a rainy appearance, and we saw a great number of meteors falling in every direction; at first I did not know what they were; afterwards I counted eight; two of them fell, leaving a stream of blue light for a second, and then vanished. I never before observed these meteors.
title: Wanderings of a pilgrim in search of the picturesque, Volume 1 (of 2)
author: Parlby, Fanny Parkes, 1794-1875

quoteFirst: After four days’ rest it returned to the trenches, placing two companies in the front line and two companies in reserve, and carrying out inter-company relief. On the 10th of February,
quoteLast: , the enemy launched a bombing attack, and tried to raid the two right posts of the right companies, but it was a half-hearted affair, and the enemy succeeded in reaching the wire in front of our trenches; the Lewis-gun and rifle fire was too strong for them, and none of the bombs they threw reached our men.
title: The Grenadier Guards in the Great War of 1914-1918, Vol. 2 of 3
author: Ponsonby, Frederick, 1867-1935

quoteFirst: We started away from that reunion at
quoteLast: and everybody was sorry to see us go. Those scouts, and the Uncle Tom’s Cabin people, and a lot of old veterans, all crowded around us to say good-by.

quoteFirst: “Next morning, the 5th of March (a day to be remembered in the annals of the Thirteenth Hussars), we moved off
quoteLast: and proceeded up the Tigris, in the teeth of a terrible sand-storm, which blinded both horses and men, and through which we could only see 80 to 100 yards ahead of us. Suddenly, out to our front, we heard the sound of rifle-fire, and bullets whizzed amongst us.
title: The Thirteenth Hussars in the Great War
author: Durand, H. Mortimer (Henry Mortimer), 1850-1924

quoteLast: . Capt. Freebody went up to York in the pinnace to Gett provisions and Leave to beat about for more hands. att 1 PM. the Pinnace Returned and brought word to the Capt. from Mr. Freebody that he had waited on his Honour the Govr.
title:
Privateering and Piracy in the Colonial Period
Illustrative Documents
author: Jameson, J. Franklin (John Franklin), 1859-1937 [Editor]

quoteFirst: I came to Rome on the 4th of November, 1644,
quoteLast: ; and being perplexed for a convenient lodging, wandered up and down on horseback, till at last one conducted us to Monsieur Petit's, a Frenchman, near the Piazza Spagnola. Here I alighted, and, having bargained with my host for twenty crowns a month, I caused a good fire to be made in my chamber and went to bed, being so very wet.
title: The Diary of John Evelyn (Volume 1 of 2)
author: Evelyn, John, 1620-1706; Garnett, Richard, 1835-1906 [Commentator]; Bray, William, 1736-1832 [Editor]

quoteFirst: An hour later, a more important, though by no means a strong, shock occurred; this was perceptible all over the Riviera, in Piedmont, and in Corsica; in other words, it disturbed a region agreeing closely with the central area of the disastrous shock. At
quoteLast: , a fifth shock, somewhat weaker than the preceding, was felt over the same area, concurrently, or nearly so, with another abnormal oscillation of the tide-gauge at Genoa; while a sixth shock was noticed at several places a few minutes before the great shock.
title: A Study of Recent Earthquakes
author: Davison, Charles, 1858-1940

quoteFirst: All this took us till long after dark on the 2nd, so that when Graviot, his wife, and daughter landed
quoteLast: on the 3rd, we were both fast asleep, so much so indeed that they had difficulty in finding our whereabouts and awakening us. At last, by rattling at the windows we were aroused, and turned out to bid the old couple and their pretty daughter, Marie, welcome to Jethou.
title: Jethou; or, Crusoe Life in the Channel Isles
author: Suffling, Ernest R. (Ernest Richard), 1855-1911

quoteLast: , after a hurricane bombardment which broke down all communications in the sector, the Germans, screened by a mist, carried the battered site on which had stood Spanbroekmolen Mill, the 64th Brigade being forced to throw out a defensive flank 500 yards north of the former on the line Somer Farm-North House-Black Cot, whence it was continued to the Vierstraat line by two companies of the Black Watch.
title: The history of the 9th (Scottish) Division, 1914-1919
author: Ewing, John, M.C.; Plumer of Messines, Herbert Charles Onslow Plumer, Viscount, 1857-1932 [Author of introduction, etc.]; Churchill, Winston, 1874-1965 [Illustrator]; Hodge, F. E. (Francis Edwin), 1883-1949 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Wangaratta. I arrived here with five men
quoteLast: We were at once challenged by police, and answered, 'Wangaratta police.' My men were then distributed around the hut, and I got to the tree near the back door of the hut. There was no firing then.
title: The Last of the Bushrangers: An Account of the Capture of the Kelly Gang
author: Hare, Francis Augustus

quoteFirst: Accordingly I marched immediately towards Montay in a thick drizzling rain, which made this dismal country appear ten times more dismal. The cavalry regiments marched at the same time (
quoteLast: ?) and we kept company as far as Montay; but there they left us, for we found the road again so choked with baggage, &c., that although we succeeded in passing the bridge, yet the deep hollow road (_encaissé_ between very high steep banks), ascending to the opposite heights, was so inextricably crammed with carriages, and the unctuous soil so slippery, that I feared we should bivouac in the churchyard again.
title: Journal of the Waterloo campaign, vol. 2 (of 2)
author: Mercer, Cavalié, 1783-1868

quoteFirst: They began again with heavier shells--Jack Johnsons--
title: The Incomparable 29th and the "River Clyde"
author: Davidson, George, 1863-1947
